headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome to the Airgas Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now for opening remarks and introductions, I would turn the call over to Vice President of Communications and Investor Relations, Jay Worley. Pleas
componenttext: Good morning and welcome to the Airgas Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now for opening remarks and introductions, I would turn the call over to Vice President of Communications and Investor Relations, Jay Worley. Please go ahead.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for attending our third quarter earnings teleconference. Joining me today are Peter McCausland, Chairman and CEO; Mike Molinini, Executive Vice President and COO; and Bob McLaughlin, Senior Vice President and CFO. Our earnings
componenttext: Good morning, and thank you for attending our third quarter earnings teleconference. Joining me today are Peter McCausland, Chairman and CEO; Mike Molinini, Executive Vice President and COO; and Bob McLaughlin, Senior Vice President and CFO. Our earnings press release was made public yesterday afternoon, and is available on our website as are the teleconference slides. To follow along, please go to www.airgas.com, click on the Investors shortcut at the top of the screen, and go to the Earnings Calls and Events page.  During the course of our presentation, we will make reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please note that reconciliations to the most comparable GAAP measures can be found in our earnings release in the slide presentation and on our website. This teleconference will contain forward-looking statements based on current expectations regarding important risk factors, which are identified in the earnings release and in our slide presentation. Actual results may differ materially from these statements, so we ask that you please note our Safe Harbor language. We'll take questions after concluding our prepared remarks, and we plan to end the teleconference by 10:00 Eastern time.  Now I'll turn the call over to Peter to begin our review.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jay, and good morning, and thanks for joining us. Slide 2 will highlight some of the key points I'll cover today and the reason why we believe that we are stronger than ever as a company, on the right track and poised to capitalize as the economy
componenttext: Thanks, Jay, and good morning, and thanks for joining us. Slide 2 will highlight some of the key points I'll cover today and the reason why we believe that we are stronger than ever as a company, on the right track and poised to capitalize as the economy recovers.Earnings were slightly below guidance for our third quarter fiscal 2010, and that's clearly not how we like to do things. Nonetheless, our performance was strong. The key factors in the earnings midst were weaker than expected sales during the holiday season, and the cancellation or postponement of plant turnarounds negatively impacting our very profitable Rental Welder business.On the bright side, this quarter marked the first sequential increase in our daily sales rate since our second quarter of fiscal 2009. And we generated record year-to-date free cash flow of $289 million.  In spite of the challenges in our Red-D-Arc Rental Welder business that I just mentioned, our Distribution segment posted healthy results, including a 2% sequential increase in daily sales, and a sequential expansion in operating margin.Our guidance this year has been predicated on a moderate case of sequential economic recovery, and we continue to hold that expectation. It may take more time to unfold than we hoped, but a recovery does seem to be underway across most of our geographies and customer segments.As we conveyed to you at our analyst meeting in December, we are very confident in our ability to drive above market results on the strength of the growth accelerators we outlined: Service to multi-location customers, cross-sell opportunities, our customer service culture, technology implementations, increasing regulation, favorable demographics and demand for supply chain management and other services, including our eCommerce offerings.Our strategic accounts customer base continues to grow, adding mass to our book of business, and our strategic products continue to outperform and effectively diversify our offering and provide stability. As the premier U.S. Packaged Gas distributor, we're in a strong position to capitalize on an improving economy.To recap the third quarter, net earnings for the third quarter were $46.9 million or $0.56 per diluted share. Excluding a $0.05 debt extinguishment charge and a $0.04 multi-employer pension plan withdrawal charge, adjusted earnings per diluted share were $0.65. This compares to a very strong $0.76 per diluted share last year. Earnings were $0.02 below the bottom of our guided range, primarily due to the unseasonably low sales in our Rental Welder business, which accounted for $0.02, and slower than expected daily sales activity in December, which accounted for another $0.02.Total sales in from the quarter declined 13% to $942 million, driven by a total same-store sales decline of 14%, with price down 3% and volume down 11%. The price declines were most pronounced in our ammonia and welding filler metals products, as declining costs accounted for the price movement. Overall, our gross margins expanded. Gas and Rent same-store sales declined 11%, and Hardgoods, 19%. Acquisitions contributed sales growth of 1%.On a sequential basis, total sales declined by 2% from the second quarter, reflecting the impact of fewer selling days and the seasonality of certain businesses in the all other operations segment. Total daily sales increased 1% from the second quarter. In the Distribution segment, we were encouraged by the 2% sequential increase in daily sales.Looking across our geographies, our Pacific Northwest region posted the smallest year-over-year declines, followed by Airgas National Welders, which covers the Carolinas in Southern Virginia. The deepest declines took place in our mid-South and Southwest region, where oil field service activity continues to be slow and in our North Central region where construction activity has tapered off. We continue to benefit from a product mix shift towards Gas and Rent sales, which represent 65% of total sales in the quarter.Year-over-year, comps remain tough for most of our customer segments and will ease next quarter. We were pleased to see a sequential increase in sales to our industrial manufacturing customers. Utilities and Petrochemical, along with our always steady Medical business, posted the strongest sequential growth on a daily sales basis. Activity with our contractor customers that served new construction and repair and maintenance projects decreased sequentially, challenging our Packaged Gas, Hardgoods and Rental Welder business. A lack of funding seems to have brought major projects to a halt and plant turnarounds are being postponed.  Overall, Hardgoods sales continue to be under the most volume pressure, led by steep declines in equipment, which is the only product line we sell that is a capital purchase for our customers.We expect equipment to drop deepest in the downturn, followed by filler metals used in manufacturing. Fortunately, these tend to be the lower margin sales compared to the rest of Hardgoods. Additionally, sales mix from Hardgoods to Gas and Rent drives gross margin expansion as Gas and Rent carry higher gross margins than in Hardgoods. Our Gas gross margin also benefited from lower costs, partially offset by lower prices. Total company margin expanded 220 basis points from last year. This gross margin expansion work in conjunction with our cost-reduction efforts to minimize operating margin erosion. Adjusted for multi-employer pension plan withdrawal charges, our operating margin only dropped 110 basis points to 11.1% from 12.2% last year, and 50 basis points from 11.6% in the second quarter.Cash flow continues to be one of the strengths of our business model. Year-to-date, free cash flow increased to a record $289 million, a 69% increase over the prior year and representing about 10% of our sales. Adjusted cash flow from operations grew 8% from $436 million last year to $470 million this year. And capital spending dropped by 32% to $192 million. Roughly 2/3 of our free cash flow has been used for debt reduction, about $190 million so far.We were pleased to increase our dividend again, as our strong cash flow allows us to reward shareholders while still pursuing our growth strategies. This was our fifth dividend increase in the past three years, and it will result in a 36% increase in dividends per share paid in fiscal 2010 over 2009.Acquisition activity has been slow as potential sellers assess their business in the wake of the downturn. However, our pipeline has been recovering recently as the anticipation of improving business conditions has stirred some interest. Year-to-date, we've acquired five businesses with an aggregate of $47 million in annual revenues.In our largest transaction this year, we acquired Tri-Tech, a very well-run, highly profitable independent distributor, with 16 locations throughout Georgia, Florida and South Carolina, generating $31 million in annual revenue. We also improved our presence and density in Oklahoma and West Texas with our purchase of Fitch Industrial & Welding Supply, a Lawton, Oklahoma-based distributor with around $10 million in annual revenues. Most recently, we added a small distributor in Houston called Champ Sales [ph], representing about $3 million to revenue.Our acquisition activity has historically accelerated during the recovery phase of a business cycle, and we hope that recent developments in the pipeline are signs of sustainable improvement. Our strategy is unchanged, we have the capacity to purchase and integrate quality businesses, and we remained diligent in sourcing transactions. We will continue to evaluate international opportunities as they arise, but our primary focus remains on domestic core products and service offering acquisitions.Looking forward, in the fourth quarter, our Packaged Gas business should pose another sequential improvement, which will be slightly offset by seasonality in the all other operations segment and continued pressure in our Rental Welder business. January sales have us off to a good start, showing slight sequential improvement from last quarter. Actually, Gas sales are up 5% to 6%, and we expect the month of January to end with Hardgoods sales down around 1%.We intend to stay focused on our fundamental strategies, enhance our sales organization and performance and continue to train our associates as we position ourselves to emerge even stronger when recovery does take shape. We have converted many new customers to Airgas over the last 18 months, and we expect that to have a positive impact as the economy continues its recovery.Although we hate to miss our guided earnings range, and believe me, it's especially hard on me, I'm a large shareholder in the company. And I take this very, very seriously, but we're a daily sales company, and its very, very hard to know what our sales are from quarter to quarter, and especially in this quarter which ends with the holiday season. However, I really don't think $0.02 below the ends of our range is meaningful in the larger scheme of things, particularly after delivering results near the high-end of our range in the past two quarters. What is meaningful is that we're on track to deliver strong performance as the U.S. economy recovers. We think our stock is undervalued, and I would say that history confirms that. And we hope that our loyal shareholders will take this opportunity to increase their holdings.  Mike will now give us a review of market strategy and operations.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Peter, and good morning, everyone. As Peter mentioned, the business climate remains challenging. But we turned a corner by posting our first sequential increase in daily sales in the year. Encouragingly, volumes in our core business drove the i
componenttext: Thank you, Peter, and good morning, everyone. As Peter mentioned, the business climate remains challenging. But we turned a corner by posting our first sequential increase in daily sales in the year. Encouragingly, volumes in our core business drove the improvement, and Distribution segment daily sales were up in spite of a tough quarter for Red-D-Arc. Before I start the broader discussion, I'd like to touch on Red-D-Arc in a bit more detail. Our Rental Welder business primarily serves two Contractor segments. First, New Construction, and second, the Repair and Maintenance Operations of Multiple Customer segments. The New Construction segment has been slowing all year as jobs are completed and new startups are limited. However, the fall is prime outage season, and we anticipated that the fall outage season would see a normal seasonal uptick in turnaround Maintenance activity, and this is where we fell far short of expectations. The end result accounted for at least $0.02 of our earnings miss. While plant shutdowns did take place, the volume of turnaround work during the shutdowns was very low. It seems that plant utilization rates in the past few quarters have allowed customers to minimize the repair and maintenance work during this outage cycle, or indefinitely postponed major plant turnarounds. Often, customers made these decisions last minute. And in several large cases, after our Rental Welder equipment have already been delivered to the job site. It is difficult to determine at this time whether customers will continue to delay scheduled turnarounds or simply skip the cycle altogether.Now let's discuss our core Packaged Gas business. We have seen some increased price competition recently. We do need and deserve a broad price increase in as much as our last increase was 17 months ago. We will initiate a pricing action at the appropriate time to achieve the optimal result. And in the meantime, we'll continue to address pricing tactically in local markets where it makes the most sense.We are focused on achieving real gains through new business signings while cross selling to our existing customer base and building market position. As Peter mentioned, we have many ways to accelerate our sales growth beyond market rates, and we believe we are doing so even in this economy. Our sales and marketing strategy focused on segment alignment is taking shape. Success thus far has been most pronounced in the strategic accounts program where it originated, and was already underway in the Medical and Construction segments. For the third quarter, Strategic Accounts business was down 8% from the prior year, as the benefit of new accounts signings across all customer segments continue to be outpaced by the year-over-year declines in our existing Metal Fabrication, Construction and Petrochemical customer base. For customers with multiple location, our strategic account focus offers superior service and supply chain savings through our national infrastructure, breadth and depth of products and services and technical expertise. Customers facing tougher times tend to renew their interest in supply chain savings, and we have been busy responding to customer inquiries. Momentum is beginning to build in our more recently aligned sales and marketing segments, including Retail, Energy, Metal Fabrication, Food and Beverage, Chemicals and Pharmaceuticals and Laboratories. When the economy recovers, this part of our business is positioned for a strong growth.Turning to Slide 3, our strategic products which combine to make up about 40% of our revenue, declined 4% for the quarter comparing favorably to the overall same-store sales decline of 14%. Sequentially, daily sales for total strategic products improved by 2% from the second quarter. Our strategic products, as a group continue to have good long-term growth profiles as many of our growth accelerators impact their performance. Safety products sales declined 5% year-over-year in the quarter comparing favorably to the overall Hardgoods same-store sales decline of 19%, and partially reflecting the impact of last years' Boeing strike on our third quarter last year. On a sequential basis, daily sales of safety products were up 3%, although low operating rates and rising unemployment are headwinds, safety products still present a strong cross-sell opportunity for us as the value and vendor consolidation is greater for our customers in today's economy.Both Gas sales were down 5% for the quarter compared to prior year. On a daily sales basis however, bulk sales increased by almost 5% sequentially, and sales of bulk nitrogen for food freezing applications continued to show strength and bulk sales to Industrial Manufacturing customers began to recover in segments such as Steel, Auto and Alternative Energy. Bulk sales continue to represent significant opportunity for us due to a combination of our extensive sales presence, full range of supply modes and ability to engineer solutions for customer needs. Medical sales grew 2% year-over-year and 3% sequentially in daily sales. While slowing in elective and non-critical procedures has reduced overall medical demand, we continue to expand our Medical business through new customer signings.Our proprietary Walk-O2-Bout cylinders, Bulk Capabilities and new Medical Gas Piping and Certification business, combined with our core Medical Package Gases offering have allowed us to cross-sell and expand business with existing customers, and have proven to be successful in helping us win new key customers, including some of the top hospitals in the country.Specialty Gas sales declined 7% year-over-year, driven largely by slowing in chemical processing industries. Sequentially however, Specialty Gas sales improved by almost 4% on a daily sales basis driven by a broad-based increase in demand for core Specialty Gases, including further strengthening of our market position and EPA protocol gases.As we highlighted during our December 15 analyst meeting, we remain extremely optimistic about our growth prospects, given our expanding account base in the biotech, life sciences, research and environmental monitoring fields. Our ability to drive the industry forward through the pursuit of new technologies and automation and increasing regulation globally. In addition, our investment in proprietary automated production and automated analytical technology, now fully deployed at all of our major Specialty Gas cylinder production plants, provides the quality and the capacity we will need to service future growth.Finishing out our strategic products, CO2 and Dry Ice were down 5% from last year, as increases in sales for food and industrial freezing applications was more than offset by lower surcharges compared to prior year. Sequentially, CO2 and Dry Ice were down on a daily sales basis due to the seasonality in those businesses. RADNOR private label products were down 18% for the quarter, slightly less than the overall drop in Hardgoods volumes. Long-term growth opportunity for our RADNOR private label products remain strong. In addition to building brand loyalty within our customer base, RADNOR products enhanced our profitability because they carry gross margins higher than comparable OEM products by 1.5x or more.In contrast with the rest of our Gas business, ammonia, which is the main product of Airgas Specialty Products, posted a sales decline in excess of 30% for the quarter. Volumes actually increased 4% in the quarter, but were more than offset by pricing, driven by the impact of falling costs compared to very high levels in the ammonia industry last year. In spite of lower volumes, our gross margin percent on ammonia improved over last year, as costs decline greater than selling prices. Similarly, refrigerants are down year-over-year as economic conditions and mild weather have fostered indefinite delays in the maintenance of HVAC Systems and elective refrigerants conversion projects that typically take place around this time of the year. The buying patterns of our refrigerant customers have changed significantly during the downturn. Looking forward, it is difficult to determine at this time whether the pre-season buy that typically takes place in March will materialize. Our operating efficiency programs, which focus on cylinder maintenance and testing distribution of fill plant logistics and freight and fuel management are progressing according to schedule. We've achieved $10 million in annual run rate savings this fiscal year, composed largely of UT cylinder test benefits distribution logistics initiatives and common carrier freight reductions.At our December analyst meeting, we set a goal to attain $40 million of new operating efficiency savings over the next four years, driven largely by a logistics plant cylinder studies and cylinder testing, cost containment and operating efficiencies have become a significant element of the Airgas operating culture, and we are confident in our ability to deliver on our goals.To date, we have fully implemented $57 million of annual expense reductions since the downturn began last year, representing more than 7% of our annual run rate EBITDA at the time. In light of the result and outlook for our Rental Welder business, we are evaluating the cost structure of that business. Excluding the Rental Welder business, we feel that our cost structure is appropriate for the current demand levels. We are able to make additional reductions if conditions deteriorate further, but we intend to balance short-term profit protection with long-term strategy for creating shareholder value.  Now Bob will give our financial review of the quarter.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to start today by reviewing our segment results. Please turn to Slide 4. As I go through these results, please note that we have GAAP reconciliations for various metrics on Slides 9 through 13.Peter and M
componenttext: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to start today by reviewing our segment results. Please turn to Slide 4. As I go through these results, please note that we have GAAP reconciliations for various metrics on Slides 9 through 13.Peter and Mike have talked about the drivers of the earnings shortfall and contrasted them with a relatively positive fundamentals of our core business. The segment results paint that picture pretty clearly, so we'll start there. Distribution sales in the quarter were down 12% versus prior year to $852 million, with same-store sales down 14%. On a sequential basis, Distribution sales decreased 1% from the second quarter. However, since there were fewer selling days in the third quarter, our Distribution sales actually improved by 2% sequentially on a daily sales basis.Distribution Gas and Rent same-store sales were down 10% year-over-year, with volumes down 8% and pricing down 2%. This is also the category that suffered the most direct impact of the Red-D-Arc shortfall in Rental revenues, which were down more than 20% from last year. Distribution Hardgoods same-store sales were down 19%, with volumes down 17% and pricing down 2%. Declines in costs and prices for filler metals were the most pronounced impact on Hardgoods pricing, with most other product lines slightly down or stable. Both Hardgoods and Gas and Rent sales improved sequentially on a daily sales basis.Distribution gross margin was 56.2%, an increase of 180 basis points over the prior year, reflecting a favorable sales mix shift to Gas and Rent. Sequentially, Distribution gross margin improved 10 basis points, with the mix of Gas and Rent sales consistent at approximately 61%. Excluding multi-employer pension plan withdrawal charges, adjusted operating income in the Distribution segment was $94 million, down 20% from the prior year and flat sequentially. The related operating margin was 11.1%, a decline of 110 basis points year-over-year, and an increase of 10 basis points sequentially. Our Distribution operating margins held up relatively well in light of the significant year-over-year sales decline due to aggressive reduction of operating expenses. We implemented $57 million of company-wide annual expense reductions since December 2008, of which a significant portion benefited the Distribution segment. The favorable mix shift to Gas and Rent also helped our operating margins.All other operations reflect our CO2, Dry Ice, Refrigerants, Ammonia and Nitrous Oxide business units. Sales for all other operations were down 18% from the prior year, in both in total and on a same-store basis. The decline was driven largely by lower pricing in ammonia products related to a corresponding drop in raw materials and lower wholesale Refrigerant volumes, reflecting sluggish contractor demand. Sequentially, the sales decline was driven by normal seasonality in the Dry Ice and Carbonic businesses, as well as the challenging business conditions in Refrigerants that Mike mentioned earlier.Operating income for all other operations was down 21% from the prior year. Operating margin decreased 50 basis points, driven primarily by margin compression in the Refrigerants business as a result of the volume declines. Sequentially, the 450 basis point decline in operating margin is primarily attributable to the normal seasonal decline of CO2, Dry Ice and Refrigerants sales. The all other operations segments was the driver of the entire sequential decline in our consolidated operating margin.Now turn Slide 5 and we'll look at our consolidated results. Sales declined 13% year-over-year to $942 million, reflecting acquisition growth of 1% and a total same-store sales decline of 14%, comprised of an 11% decline in Gas and Rent, and a 19% decline in Hardgoods. Volume was down 11% and price was down 3%. As mentioned in the segment discussion, declines in costs and prices for ammonia are the most pronounced impact in the Gas and Rent sales. In the same dynamic, impacted Filler Metals and Hardgoods sales.Sequentially, sales declined 2%, driven primarily by fewer selling days and the seasonality discussed in the all other operation segment. However, on a daily sales basis, sales rose sequentially by 1%. Gas and Rent represented almost 65% of our sales mix, comparing favorably with the prior year mix of just over 62%. The sales mix shift is driven by the relative strength of Gas and Rent same-store sales compared to Hardgoods. The favorable Gas-Rent mix is also reflected in our 55.8% gross margin for the quarter, an increase of 220 basis points over the prior year. As mentioned in the Distribution segment discussion, gross margin was up 10 basis points sequentially, reflecting stable relationships between costs and pricing across most products.Excluding pretax multi-employer pension plan charges, operating income for the quarter was $105 million, down 20% from last year. While operating margins were negatively impacted by the significant year-over-year decline in sales, the $57 million in annual expense reductions that we implemented between December 2008 and September 2009, in addition to our ongoing operating efficiency initiatives, significantly mitigated the impact on our operating margins. Our adjusted operating margin, which excludes pretax multi-employer pension plan charges, held up relatively well for the quarter at 11.1%, a decline of 110 basis points year-over-year, and 50 basis points sequentially. The sequential decline is entirely attributable to the normal seasonal decline in our all other operations segment.We continue our efforts to withdraw from multi- employer pension plans, and we're successful to a significant degree this quarter. We entered the year with 12 collective bargaining agreements that contain multi-employer pension plans, and thus far, have exited six. The remaining six agreements, which cover approximately 80 employees, come up for renewal between now and the end of fiscal 2012.Adjusted earnings per diluted share of $0.65 in the second quarter represents a decline of 14% year-over-year and a decline of 4% sequentially. We were short of our guidance due to a $0.02 impact of the challenging conditions in our Rental Welder business and a $0.02 impact from a weaker than expected sales finish in the quarter. Including a $0.05 loss on the early extinguishment of debt related to the previously-announced redemption of our $150 million 6 1/4 notes and a $0.04 charge for multi-employer pension plan withdrawals, GAAP earnings were $0.56 per diluted share. There were approximately 84 million weighted diluted shares outstanding for the quarter, up about 1% year-over-year and fundamentally flat on a sequential basis.Return on capital was 10.1%, a 340 basis point decline from the prior year, primarily driven by the slowing economy and related decline in operating income. With respect to accounts receivable, our collection rates for the quarter have remained relatively consistent both year-over-year and sequentially, and our quarterly DSO of 48 days was consistent with the second quarter results. Inventory turns held consistently with recent trends and inventory reductions have contributed more than $45 million to our cash flow this year. Year-to-date, free cash flow was $289 million compared to $171 million last year, driven by strong adjusted from cash from operations of $470 million, up from $436 million last year. And by a 32% reduction in capital expenditures to $192 million this year. We increased our dividend for the fourth quarter by 22% to $0.22 per share, representing a 36% increase in dividends per share paid in fiscal 2010 over 2009.Adjusted debt at December 31 was $1.9 billion, and $523 million was available under our revolving credit facility. Adjusted debt has been reduced by approximately $300 million since December 2008 and a little more than $190 million year-to-date in fiscal 2010. Our fixed flow of ratio at the end of December was 53% fixed and our adjusted debt to EBITDA ratio was 2.7% in the middle of our recently revised target range of 2% to 3%.Slide 6 is one that we introduced at our analyst meeting in December and it serves to demonstrate some of the defensive and resilient financial aspects of our performance, as well as where we seem to be in the economic cycle. A review of the EBITDA line reveals a remarkably gentle slope when compared to the magnitude of the same store sales decline that we experienced in the past four quarters. The work we have done to diversify our customer base and product mix, the relatively stable nature of our rental revenue stream and the quick effective expense reductions we implemented in the downturn, served to hold EBITDA relatively flat in this challenging sales environment.  The result is an expanded EBITDA margin compared to the peak quarters of just over a year ago. Secondly, the sequential change in daily sales show that after period of sharp decreases, we just posted our first sequential increase in the year. The timing of the sequential declines suggest that the Packaged Gas business lagged the downturn slightly and is exhibiting these characteristics coming out of it as well.Please turn to Slide 7, capital expenditures. Capital spending was $192 million fiscal year-to-date versus $282 million last year. Spending on cylinders, bulk tanks and rental welders declined as sales have slowed, and overall capital spending was down 32% compared to the prior year. Excluding the impact of major capital projects, year-to-date capital spending is about 4% of sales. We are still on pace to realize our target of reducing capital expenditures by more than $100 million in this fiscal year.Slide 8, presents a walk through the primary elements of our fourth quarter guidance using the third quarter adjusted EPS of $0.65 as the starting point. The $0.04 headwind we have is related to two dynamics. One is the normal seasonal slowing of our Dry Ice and Carbonic businesses, as colder weather alleviate the demand for some of these products. The second is our expectation of further pressure on our Rental Welder business, associated with sluggish construction activity, which we do not expect to turn up in the near-term. At our backs, the absence of the holiday season should help us with a couple extra pennies, and the big additions come from modest sequential increase in the core business, supported by an improving economy, an additional selling day, and incremental operating efficiencies. We expect negative same-store sales in the low single digits, representing a slow steady pace of recovery. We expect earnings per share to be in the range of $0.67 to $0.71 in the fourth quarter, roughly flat to slightly up from last year. The high end of the range assumes an improving economic environment, particularly related to industrial manufacturing.Please note that the fourth quarter guidance does not incorporate the impact of any future multi-employer pension plan withdrawal charges. As we continue our efforts to withdraw from such plants, although we do not anticipate material charges in our fourth quarter. We also reiterate that prevailing economic conditions offer limited visibility into future sales and earnings, which should be taken into consideration when evaluating our guidance. I'll now turn it back over to Jay to begin the Q&A portion of the call.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: That concludes our prepared remarks. As we begin the Q&A portion of our call we ask that you limit yourselves to two question and one follow up. The operator will now give instructions for asking questions.
componenttext: That concludes our prepared remarks. As we begin the Q&A portion of our call we ask that you limit yourselves to two question and one follow up. The operator will now give instructions for asking questions.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Robert Koort of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Robert Koort of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, Peter, if you could maybe give an assessment of what you expect the path of your same-store sales recovery to be and along with the U.S. economy? I guess specifically non-tech IP, and then if you put it in the context of a historical pres
componenttext: I was wondering, Peter, if you could maybe give an assessment of what you expect the path of your same-store sales recovery to be and along with the U.S. economy? I guess specifically non-tech IP, and then if you put it in the context of a historical present is there something different based in what you've done around the cost structure in the portfolio that would make a recovery profile different now than maybe it was at the early 2000 recession?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, I think we've outperformed non-tech IP for the most part over the last eight years. There were quarters where we dipped a little bit below it, but for the most part, we've outperformed and because of our strategic products and our strategic
componenttext: First of all, I think we've outperformed non-tech IP for the most part over the last eight years. There were quarters where we dipped a little bit below it, but for the most part, we've outperformed and because of our strategic products and our strategic accounts program. So I think that we'll run ahead of it as it improves. And I think in terms of what might be different in this recovery, I do feel that our cost reduction and our efficiency programs have a lot of momentum. They really became a part of our culture. We're launching new programs, we've got good technology that we're deploying. So that's going to be different and should help our fall through as sales increase. And I would also say that we've added a lot of customers to our roles in the last 18 months, and I really think that, that's going to give us somewhat of an extra kick as the economy recovers. So I think there's a few things different this time, which will benefit us more than in the past, but I also expect that we are going to run ahead of non-tech industrial production.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Any chance you can give us some sense of what you think if we were back to a normal sort of 3% growth rate given the current asset base where a normalized margins might fall?
componenttext: Any chance you can give us some sense of what you think if we were back to a normal sort of 3% growth rate given the current asset base where a normalized margins might fall?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's really hard to say. We do have the benefit of a more efficient organization, there's no question about it. So fall through might be better, coming out of this recession than the last one as a result of that. There's no question about it. Our
componenttext: I think it's really hard to say. We do have the benefit of a more efficient organization, there's no question about it. So fall through might be better, coming out of this recession than the last one as a result of that. There's no question about it. Our gas and hardgoods mix has improved as well, which is going to help that. So I think that once we get in the year end of this recovery, I would expect that our EBITDA margins would get back to where they were and hopefully exceeds our peak margins that we experienced in the last recovery.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I would add to that Peter, we did put out a kind of fiscal '13 to '14 financial goals at our December analyst meeting and we talked about operating margins in the 13% to 14% and return on capital on the 14½% to 15½% range for all the reasons that  P
componenttext: And I would add to that Peter, we did put out a kind of fiscal '13 to '14 financial goals at our December analyst meeting and we talked about operating margins in the 13% to 14% and return on capital on the 14½% to 15½% range for all the reasons that  Peter articulated, it is definitely within our site assuming economic conditions to get to those levels. So significant upside from where we are at today.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, just to supplement that, we've increased our gross profit nicely in this recession, albeit part of it is mix, but part of it is declining costs to produce gases and buy gases, partially offset by some lower prices. But it's been quite a while since w
componenttext: Bob, just to supplement that, we've increased our gross profit nicely in this recession, albeit part of it is mix, but part of it is declining costs to produce gases and buy gases, partially offset by some lower prices. But it's been quite a while since we've had an across-the-board pricing increase. I would hope that as its recovery -- we're planning on price increases as the recovery gets a firmer hold here and the energy markets have all risen from their order loads and that should give us some favorable banging for price increases.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Mike Sison from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Mike Sison from KeyBanc.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the same-store sales outlook for the fourth quarter, any particular areas that you need to see, to see that improvement year-over-year relative to steeper declines in the previous three quarters?
componenttext: In terms of the same-store sales outlook for the fourth quarter, any particular areas that you need to see, to see that improvement year-over-year relative to steeper declines in the previous three quarters?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mean, areas in the economy?
componenttext: You mean, areas in the economy?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: In your markets. Same-store sales are going to lowsingle digits, any particular areas that you're sort of banking on CD improvement?
componenttext: In your markets. Same-store sales are going to lowsingle digits, any particular areas that you're sort of banking on CD improvement?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the core Metal Fab business we are hoping is going to come back, we can imagine it going lower and it has started to improve slightly in the last quarter. And petrochemicals and chemicals also showed improvement. So they are important to us and so c
componenttext: Well, the core Metal Fab business we are hoping is going to come back, we can imagine it going lower and it has started to improve slightly in the last quarter. And petrochemicals and chemicals also showed improvement. So they are important to us and so continued improvement is going to be important to our same-store sales progress. As I mentioned, our gas sales are up over December levels and January, 5% to 6%, which is pretty nice and that's without any price increase. And we expect hardgoods to come in at about 1% below December at this rate. But combined, it's going to be a solid same-store sales performance for January, and we just hope it carries on into February and through March. This tends to be our strongest quarter. We are cautiously optimistic that it will develop positively.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if the economic environment continues to improve, would you expect sort of your same-store sales to turn positive as you head into 2011?
componenttext: And if the economic environment continues to improve, would you expect sort of your same-store sales to turn positive as you head into 2011?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, definitely. In fact, this quarter coming up, the third quarter last year was a pretty good quarter for us, and then our fourth quarter last year, we got hit pretty hard. And so we could have positive comps on same-store sales, we will have, we think
componenttext: Yes, definitely. In fact, this quarter coming up, the third quarter last year was a pretty good quarter for us, and then our fourth quarter last year, we got hit pretty hard. And so we could have positive comps on same-store sales, we will have, we think this year, right?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: First quarter of next year, yes.
componenttext: First quarter of next year, yes.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Gulley of Soleil Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Gulley of Soleil Securities.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: One, Peter, should we take a look at the big dividend increase, and congratulations on that, has any sign whatsoever that you're pulling back on your desire to pursue acquisitions?
componenttext: One, Peter, should we take a look at the big dividend increase, and congratulations on that, has any sign whatsoever that you're pulling back on your desire to pursue acquisitions?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely not. Our dividend has lagged, our peers in industrial distribution and in industrial gases. So we wanted to bring it back up. It's also lagged the growth in our earnings cash flow from operations and free cash flow. And we have plenty of availa
componenttext: Absolutely not. Our dividend has lagged, our peers in industrial distribution and in industrial gases. So we wanted to bring it back up. It's also lagged the growth in our earnings cash flow from operations and free cash flow. And we have plenty of availability to execute on all of our growth programs, including acquisitions, and also reward our shareholders. So, not at all.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Robert, I think you commented on this before, but what would be the normalized ratio of CapEx to sales? Clearly, it looks like a cyclical low this year, but what's the normalized level?
componenttext: Robert, I think you commented on this before, but what would be the normalized ratio of CapEx to sales? Clearly, it looks like a cyclical low this year, but what's the normalized level?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well our maintenance, as we talked about, cut them down to pure maintenance is somewhere in the 3% arena. So then depending upon the level of growth that we are having within the business, it's probably in a 3% to 5% bandwidth that we're having some norma
componenttext: Well our maintenance, as we talked about, cut them down to pure maintenance is somewhere in the 3% arena. So then depending upon the level of growth that we are having within the business, it's probably in a 3% to 5% bandwidth that we're having some normal growth.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then finally, Peter, you've made some nice adjacent acquisitions over the years but not all of them have worked out, Rutland tools comes to mind. If you take a look at the portfolio now, are there any areas that perhaps haven't fit, haven't worked as
componenttext: And then finally, Peter, you've made some nice adjacent acquisitions over the years but not all of them have worked out, Rutland tools comes to mind. If you take a look at the portfolio now, are there any areas that perhaps haven't fit, haven't worked as well as you would hoped?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, Rutland was a major screwup for sure, and not just product line, but operationally we didn't do the best integration there. But no, some of them are newer like Oilind and integrating that with our sales efforts, especially in the worst recession since
componenttext: No, Rutland was a major screwup for sure, and not just product line, but operationally we didn't do the best integration there. But no, some of them are newer like Oilind and integrating that with our sales efforts, especially in the worst recession since the Great Depression, has been a challenge. But we like the business. It really fits well with our product and service offering on the maintenance products that we sell, maintenance welding and maintenance gases, as well as Red-D-Arc. And Red-D-Arc is a fabulous company and a very, very profitable company. And they've been not backed by this recession and the big decline in construction and most recently the postponement of plant turnarounds. I would say no. And looking across at some of the other new ones like ammonia, it's been a big winner. Profits are up this quarter even though prices are down because we're selling a very price-sensitive commodity. Refrigerants, another good acquisition, hasn't developed as quickly as we thought. But it fits very well with our regional companies. We have a great program where regional companies are selling refrigerants, and Airgas Refrigerants, Inc. is doing all the fulfillment. Our customers like to buy these products from us. So I would say, no. But as always it takes a long time to really get these things right, but I think we are really doing well with the ones we have.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Edward Yang of Oppenheimer for our next question.
componenttext: We'll go to Edward Yang of Oppenheimer for our next question.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Peter, Mike mentioned the erratic customer behavior in rental welders with some of the last-minute cancellations. Are there any steps you could take to minimize that volatility or is that just the nature of the business or the competitive environment prec
componenttext: Peter, Mike mentioned the erratic customer behavior in rental welders with some of the last-minute cancellations. Are there any steps you could take to minimize that volatility or is that just the nature of the business or the competitive environment precludes taking any steps?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's the nature of the business. They call you up and they want it yesterday in that business. When decisions are made for refineries or petrochemical plants that take maintenance outages either partial or a whole. We had expected Red-D-Arc to bottom a fe
componenttext: It's the nature of the business. They call you up and they want it yesterday in that business. When decisions are made for refineries or petrochemical plants that take maintenance outages either partial or a whole. We had expected Red-D-Arc to bottom a few months ago and then they came in with a pretty weak quarter. So as Mike say, we are looking hard at the cost structure there. Once before in the last recession, we took some cost reduction measures at Red-D-Arc. But it's a very profitable, very well-run business. So we think there's some things we can do, but we're not going to change the behavior of the customers. They love us because we are ready when they call. So Mike, do you have anything to add to that?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. The core business of Red-D-Arc is for large projects or turnarounds. They're generally known in advance. It's not like somebody walks up and wants to rent a welder for a week. It's usually months and months and it's usually quite a few. So these are w
componenttext: No. The core business of Red-D-Arc is for large projects or turnarounds. They're generally known in advance. It's not like somebody walks up and wants to rent a welder for a week. It's usually months and months and it's usually quite a few. So these are well-planned in advance. And up until this quarter, we've never experienced the situation where we have collected and assembled and prepared several hundred rental machines and actually delivered them to the job site only be called to say come back and get them because we're not going to do it. We've never experienced that before. So again, we're trying to get our arms around how, is this the new normal for that or what.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the dollar seems to be strengthening again, it's up more than 6% versus the euro since the fourth quarter. Has that factored into your outlook? I know you don't have much direct FX exposure, but what percentage of your customers are export-reliant and
componenttext: And the dollar seems to be strengthening again, it's up more than 6% versus the euro since the fourth quarter. Has that factored into your outlook? I know you don't have much direct FX exposure, but what percentage of your customers are export-reliant and would a stronger dollar also affect your appetite for international acquisitions?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We continue to look at international acquisitions and we're in fact actually looking at a couple of, it's pretty hard right now. But the dollar goes up and down. It really –- it's been in a sort of range-bound now for quite some time, I think. I think m
componenttext: We continue to look at international acquisitions and we're in fact actually looking at a couple of, it's pretty hard right now. But the dollar goes up and down. It really –- it's been in a sort of range-bound now for quite some time, I think. I think more importantly, a really, really strong dollar can hurt U.S. manufacturers. So I don't particularly favor it. I think the dollar has moved up because people are talking about, they are worried about Greece and other places sort of the safe haven thing. But long-term with our deficits and whatnot, I don't see a huge increase in the dollar, but I'm not an economist. I don't think U.S. manufacturing can go any lower as a percent of GDP, and we're encouraged because we're seeing the construction of a lot of new plants in the United States. They are four our five automobile manufacturing plants, Intel is building two new fabs, several other semiconductor firms are taking over fabs that were shut down, they're renovating them, there are stainless steel plants, uranium processing plants going in and solar plants. So I'm pretty positive on U.S. manufacturing going forward here. And I think the dollar will probably, that this is just a blip up and I don't see getting too much stronger and possibly it could go down.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Moving on, our next question comes from Tom Hayes of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Moving on, our next question comes from Tom Hayes of Piper Jaffray.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Regarding the pickup, it sounds like you're seeing in the January business, does it appear that the purchasing managers are just ordering the refill stock and maybe catching up for delayed December non-purchases or are we finally seeing some of the restoc
componenttext: Regarding the pickup, it sounds like you're seeing in the January business, does it appear that the purchasing managers are just ordering the refill stock and maybe catching up for delayed December non-purchases or are we finally seeing some of the restocking order to recover from the large destocking we saw over the past couple of quarters?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't have any stocking of gases so this is directly related to business activity. And most of the hardgoods, they don't carry big inventories, that's our job. We keep them in our stores and then our distribution centers for our customers. So, no, we t
componenttext: We don't have any stocking of gases so this is directly related to business activity. And most of the hardgoods, they don't carry big inventories, that's our job. We keep them in our stores and then our distribution centers for our customers. So, no, we think its directly related to the increased activity.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to David Begleiter of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll go next to David Begleiter of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Peter, you mentioned some selling price pressure in Petro gases could you give us little more color on where that is occurring and by whom and any further details?
componenttext: Peter, you mentioned some selling price pressure in Petro gases could you give us little more color on where that is occurring and by whom and any further details?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Every time there's a big recession, you have some price pressure. We had it in the last time. I think the important thing here to know is that our gross profit is up a couple of hundred basis points in packaged gas and of course, gross profit is a functio
componenttext: Every time there's a big recession, you have some price pressure. We had it in the last time. I think the important thing here to know is that our gross profit is up a couple of hundred basis points in packaged gas and of course, gross profit is a function of selling prices, mix and then also cost of sales. And cost of sales is down, both purchased products and manufactured products on the gas side. We've added a lot of new customers, and when you add new customers in this business, it tends to be at lower prices. A lot of customers have closed their doors, and longtime customers during this recession, and they tend to be at higher prices. That's the way the business works. We haven't had a general price increase for 17 months. So what we're seeing is sort of the end of recession, beginning of recovery, normal price competition. We're not concerned about it and our gross margins have actually improved.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the COGS issue, are you seeing any increases in your purchased gas prices yet or in the future?
componenttext: On the COGS issue, are you seeing any increases in your purchased gas prices yet or in the future?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: They've actually been going down because we buy 70% of our molecules and we have electricity indexes in the pricing clauses and they've been going down now. Electricity and gas, gas costs and natural gas and oil prices have gone up over the last couple of
componenttext: They've actually been going down because we buy 70% of our molecules and we have electricity indexes in the pricing clauses and they've been going down now. Electricity and gas, gas costs and natural gas and oil prices have gone up over the last couple of months. So we could have -- and we lagged. so we could have some increases a few months out. We welcome higher energy prices because that justifies us getting price increases. So we are not opposed to that.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On share buy backs, given with the stock prices today, what are your thoughts?
componenttext: On share buy backs, given with the stock prices today, what are your thoughts?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll be talking about that at our next board meeting as we do every board meeting. And at this price, it's going to get a very, very hard look.
componenttext: Yes, we'll be talking about that at our next board meeting as we do every board meeting. And at this price, it's going to get a very, very hard look.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Kevin McCarthy of Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Kevin McCarthy of Bank of America.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Peter, just to follow-up on the 5% to 6% increase that you referenced for the month of January. I was wondering if you could comment on how that compares to what you would normally experience as a seasonal trend?
componenttext: Peter, just to follow-up on the 5% to 6% increase that you referenced for the month of January. I was wondering if you could comment on how that compares to what you would normally experience as a seasonal trend?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Its 5% to 6% on gases and we're expecting hardgoods to end down 1% sequentially. So it'll be like a 3%, somewhere around there, increases. It's what we're projecting. There is a seasonal pickup in January, there's no question about it. But we're also seei
componenttext: Its 5% to 6% on gases and we're expecting hardgoods to end down 1% sequentially. So it'll be like a 3%, somewhere around there, increases. It's what we're projecting. There is a seasonal pickup in January, there's no question about it. But we're also seeing increased activity in the customer base. And so how much of it is seasonal, and how much of it is actual increased activity, I can't really say. But they're both factors in the improvement.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the Welding Hardgoods business, when you look at some of the larger ticket items there in that you would consider leading indicators, what are you seeing in terms of level of inquiries or orders in recent weeks and months? How does the trend look there
componenttext: In the Welding Hardgoods business, when you look at some of the larger ticket items there in that you would consider leading indicators, what are you seeing in terms of level of inquiries or orders in recent weeks and months? How does the trend look there?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Overall, slow. We had a pickup in December because welding machines are a capital item and a lot of people have them in their budgets and they're on an annual fiscal year, calendar fiscal year. So we saw that little blip up, but overall, slow. I'd say the
componenttext: Overall, slow. We had a pickup in December because welding machines are a capital item and a lot of people have them in their budgets and they're on an annual fiscal year, calendar fiscal year. So we saw that little blip up, but overall, slow. I'd say the one encouraging thing is, that there are still, even in this environment, some interesting automation projects under way that we're involved in with our customers. So those kinds of things are leading. But I wouldn't say it's robust at this point.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Final question for a Bob, as we approach the fiscal year end here in March, are there any year end true ups or variances that you would foresee in terms of tax rates, stock-based comp or perhaps other issues we should be keeping in mind from a modeling pe
componenttext: Final question for a Bob, as we approach the fiscal year end here in March, are there any year end true ups or variances that you would foresee in terms of tax rates, stock-based comp or perhaps other issues we should be keeping in mind from a modeling perspective, recognizing you still have a few months to go?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Nothing that's needle-moving or significant.
componenttext: Nothing that's needle-moving or significant.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll move on now to Mike Harrison of First Analysis.
componenttext: We'll move on now to Mike Harrison of First Analysis.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010

componenttext: Peter, in the Welder Rental business, do you charge customers a fee when they cancel a rental reservation like it sounds like they did this quarter?

componenttext: Not a good customer.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Also wondering if there are any new competitors in that Welder Rental business that might have had an impact on the quarter?
componenttext: Also wondering if there are any new competitors in that Welder Rental business that might have had an impact on the quarter?

componenttextpreview: No, I'd say that we're by far and away the best company in the business, and no one can compete with our fleet or our service or our technical support. And when that business comes back, we're going to do very well.
componenttext: No, I'd say that we're by far and away the best company in the business, and no one can compete with our fleet or our service or our technical support. And when that business comes back, we're going to do very well.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: The last number I had in terms of Red-D-Arc sales was in FY '07 number at $94 million. Is that still about the ballpark of where annual sales is? I'm just trying to get a sense of the magnitude of the drop off that you might have seen this quarter.
componenttext: The last number I had in terms of Red-D-Arc sales was in FY '07 number at $94 million. Is that still about the ballpark of where annual sales is? I'm just trying to get a sense of the magnitude of the drop off that you might have seen this quarter.

componenttext: I think it was somewhat broad, and as Peter mentioned, part of it was driven by our lower costs. So is as our costs went down, be it related to electricity or in some cases, fuel surcharges, as those came down, our costs came down, some of our pricing came down in some selective areas. But as Peter also mentioned, we preserved and actually slightly increased the underlying margin on our gases.

componenttext: We have about $500 million available under our $1 billion revolver that's not part of a term note. We have an AR securitization agreement that comes up in March that we are actively discussing renewal now on. And our, as you're aware, our revolving credit facility matures in July of 2011. And we're looking and preparing for that as well. But as you also know, we are enjoying significantly low rates, 50 basis points over LIBOR on our current agreement. And we just recently, a few months back, issued 400 million in 4½% bonds. And we are obviously actively looking at the bond market now given the attractiveness.

And I'm asking that because we're using one year comps and it's been such a volatile series on hardgoods that's there that the year-over-year comps I don't if they've become somewhat meaningless relative to a leading lag indicator for gas and rent?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I still think they're meaningful.
componenttext: I still think they're meaningful.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it used to be that it wasn't necessarily hardgoods, it was the equipment portion of hardgoods where capital spending kind of led the way out. Two things have changed. First are the percentage of our business that's tied to manufacturing continues
componenttext: I think it used to be that it wasn't necessarily hardgoods, it was the equipment portion of hardgoods where capital spending kind of led the way out. Two things have changed. First are the percentage of our business that's tied to manufacturing continues to decline, so the capital equipment component of what we do is really not linked. It's not as strong as it used to be. And after four or five years of robust economy prior to this, there was a tremendous amount of new investment in equipment that was put in. This recession came on so fast that I think a lot of that equipment was just shut down. It wasn't really in need of replacement, it was relatively new and they just shut it off. So my belief is, we are not necessarily going to see a huge leading indicator rebound on capital equipment this time around.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know. We've seen some positive impacts like in cryo [cryogenic] bio equipment because NIH is giving a lot of money to major research institutes. We've seen some bridge work but the overall declines in construction have sort of dwarfed that. If the
componenttext: I don't know. We've seen some positive impacts like in cryo [cryogenic] bio equipment because NIH is giving a lot of money to major research institutes. We've seen some bridge work but the overall declines in construction have sort of dwarfed that. If they increase the nuclear plant loan guarantee program, we'll see a lot of positive sales developments and things like that but the stimulus that's been enacted so far, I would tend to share practical view in terms of having very little beneficial effect on the economy or Airgas.
