headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Airgas First Quarter 2011 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introductions, I will now turn the call over to the Vice President of Communications and Investor Relations, Jay Worley. Please
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Airgas First Quarter 2011 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introductions, I will now turn the call over to the Vice President of Communications and Investor Relations, Jay Worley. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for attending our first quarter earnings teleconference. Joining me today are Peter McCausland, Chairman and CEO; Mike Molinini, Executive Vice President and COO; and Bob McLaughlin, Senior Vice President and CFO. Our earning
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for attending our first quarter earnings teleconference. Joining me today are Peter McCausland, Chairman and CEO; Mike Molinini, Executive Vice President and COO; and Bob McLaughlin, Senior Vice President and CFO. 
Our earnings press release was made public this morning and is available on our website as are the teleconference slides. To follow along, please go to airgas.com, click on the Investors shortcut at the top of the screen and then go to the Earnings Calls & Events page. 
During the course of our presentation, we will make reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please note that unless specified otherwise, metrics referred to in today's discussion will be adjusted for legal and professional fees related to Air Products' unsolicited takeover attempt, as well as for debt extinguishment and multi-employer pension plan withdrawal charges. Reconciliations to the most comparable GAAP measures can be found in our earnings release, in the slide presentation and on our website. 
This teleconference will contain forward-looking statements based on current expectations regarding important risk factors, which are identified in the earnings release and in our slide presentation. Actual results may differ materially from these statements, so we ask that you please note our Safe Harbor language. We also ask that you note the additional information and certain information regarding participants provided on Slide 1 of our slide presentation. 
We'll take questions regarding our financial and operational performance and our outlook after concluding our prepared remarks, and we plan to end the teleconference by 11 a.m. Eastern Time. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Peter to begin our review.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jay. Good morning, and thank you all for joining us. We had a great quarter at Airgas. And as I've always said, the most exciting time in Airgas is right now. We delivered the second best earnings quarter in our history, which is particularly en
componenttext:
Thanks, Jay. Good morning, and thank you all for joining us. We had a great quarter at Airgas. And as I've always said, the most exciting time in Airgas is right now. 
We delivered the second best earnings quarter in our history, which is particularly encouraging, given that at this early stage of the economic recovery, revenues have not yet recovered to pre-recession levels. 
Our business, which historically lags the economic cycle, is just starting to gather momentum in the economic recovery. In addition, Air Products' takeover attempt has cast a bright light on our business, revealing how undervalued the company was and energizing the 14,000 Airgas associates out there who make up the best team in the business from drivers and retail store personnel to our plant operators, sales force and back-office teams. We have proven year after year our ability to create real shareholder value, and as our quarterly results show, we're off to a great start in continuing that trend this year. 
Adjusted earnings per diluted share were $0.83 for the first quarter, up 26% from the prior year and up 20% sequentially. After posting strong earnings deep into the recession and solid results through the downturn, we are excited again to post double-digit earnings growth, the kind our shareholders have come to expect from Airgas. 
Before continuing with the business at hand today, I want to briefly address the Air Products' unsolicited takeover attempt, including their revised offer of $63.50 per share. The Airgas Board of Directors unanimously believes that Air Products' revised offer, like their previous offers of $60 and $62 per share, grossly undervalued Airgas. And today, we filed our 14D-9 response to that effect. 
Our reasoning, simply stated, is that Air Products' proposals do not reflect the inherent value of our future prospects. Our extraordinary track record in creating shareholder value and our position as the largest and most valuable packaged gas business in the world. They also fail to reflect our substantial recent investment and the significant opportunities for our business as the economy recovers as further evidenced by our strong first quarter earnings. 
Since Airgas' IPO in 1986, we have employed a disciplined approach to steadily growing revenue, EBITDA and shareholder equity. Airgas stock has achieved total shareholder return over that period of time, more than 7x the return of the S&P 500 index. We believe Air Products' unsolicited takeover attempt is an opportunistic effort to cut off the Airgas stockholder's ability to benefit as the domestic economy continues its recovery. It is also an effort to obtain the future value of Airgas at a bargain basement price. 
Air Products has essentially acknowledged the importance of their timing, declaring the timing of their proposals to be "excellent or ideal" as "the economy is just beginning to emerge from the recession." Indeed, our performance coming out of the last recession was robust, and we are a much stronger company today than we were then. 
Since Air Products commenced its tender offer, we delivered excellent results, and economic conditions have continued to improve. We have reduced our adjusted debt by more than $160 million since Air Products first approached us with a $60 offer in October last year, and we have now just delivered the second best earnings quarter in company history at a very early stage in the economic recovery. We believe that the improving sales climate bolsters the expectations of greater value. Our strategy through the downturn was to position Airgas to emerge from the recession as an even stronger company, and our results demonstrate our success. 
I invite you to review our materials on this topic posted in the Investor Information section of our website by clicking on the Air Products Unsolicited Proposal link. In particular, we will be posting a new presentation today entitled It's All About Value, which provides additional support for our midterm goals and we believe further strengthens our position that Air Products' offer grossly undervalues Airgas. 
Please turn to Slide 2 for a recap of the outstanding quarter we just delivered. We're excited that the world is watching our performance, and we're all very bullish on the future of Airgas. Daily sales improved by 5% sequentially, the third consecutive quarter of sequential improvement and another sign that business is strengthening. 
Total sales in the quarter were nearly $1.05 billion, an increase of 7% over the prior year, driven by a total same-store sales increase of 6%. Gas and Rent same-store sales increased 5% and Hardgoods increased 8%. Acquisitions contributed sales growth of 1%. Also, as expected, Hardgoods continue to lead the recovery. 
Conditions continue to improve in most of our customer segments and geographies this quarter, led by Manufacturing and with the greatest strength in our Great Lakes region. We again expanded our book of business with another very strong quarter of signings in our Strategic Accounts program, which was established specifically for multi-location customers who benefit from sole-source supply and supply chain management services. Companies across a variety of industries continue to embrace the value proposition inherent in our integrated product and service offerings. 
In light of the accelerating pace of cost increases as the economy recovers, we announced our first broad-based price increase on gas, rent and hardgoods in nearly two years effective June 1. The price increase has been successful thus far, but we do not expect to realize the full benefits until the September quarter. 
Cash flow continues to be one of the strengths of our business model, and the first quarter was no exception. Free cash flow of $113 million resulted from $171 million of adjusted cash flow from operations and continued CapEx discipline. We reduced our adjusted debt by $83 million during the quarter, and we're pleased to increase our dividends to $0.25 per share on the strength of our outstanding performance and future prospects. 
Our acquisition activity has historically accelerated during the recovery phase of the business cycle, and we hope that recent developments in the pipeline are signs of sustainable improvement. Year-to-date, we have acquired four small businesses with aggregate annual revenues of $5 million. 
Our acquisition strategy is unchanged. We have capacity to purchase and integrate quality businesses, and we remain diligent in sourcing transaction. We will continue to evaluate international opportunities as they arise, but our primary focus remains on domestic core product and service offering acquisition. 
Looking forward, in the second quarter, we expect another sequential improvement in daily sales. June finished well above our first quarter average daily sales, and given holiday and seasonal consideration, July is tracking well. The strengthening in our business and our robust result give us the confidence to raise our fiscal 2011 guidance by more than 7% from the previously announced range to a new range of $3.15 to $3.30 per share, which is an 18% to 23% increase over fiscal 2010. 
As I mentioned earlier, our strategy was to position Airgas to emerge an even stronger company in the economic recovery, and our results are testament to the success of that strategy as we are running very close to record earnings and margin. We intend to stay focused on our fundamental strategies, enhance our sales organization and performance and continue to train our associates as we position Airgas to drive significant shareholder value creation during the recovery. 
Mike will now give us a review of market strategy and operations.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Peter, and good morning, everyone. As Peter mentioned, we're seeing a lot of momentum in our business at this early stage of recovery. This morning, I'm going to give you a few examples of metrics we watch to illustrate this momentum. Then I'll
componenttext:
Thank you, Peter, and good morning, everyone. As Peter mentioned, we're seeing a lot of momentum in our business at this early stage of recovery. This morning, I'm going to give you a few examples of metrics we watch to illustrate this momentum. Then I'll review operating results, and I'll finish with a brief update on our SAP implementation. 
Welding Hardgoods are a critical element of the offering in the U.S. Packaged Gas business. They also provide some useful leading indicators for us, both in total and also in end product categories. In general, Hardgoods same-store sales lead Gas and Rent same-store sales in the recovery. 
In the first quarter, our daily sales of equipment were up sequentially 1% from the fourth quarter. Equipment, which consist primarily of welding and cutting machines, represents the capital purchase for our customers, and equipment sales tend to rise as customers invest in their business for future productions. Daily sales of filler metals increased 11% sequential. Customer production rates drive a significant portion of filler metal demand and account for most of the improvement. 
Another measure of hardgood activity is the number of invoice line items picked and shipped from our distribution centers to our branches and customers. The hardgoods in this category are primarily welding and gas-handling accessories and safety supplies. First quarter lines shipped from our DCs increased by more than 10% from the fourth quarter. 
In the Gas business, production, distribution and asset management are key drivers of profitability and returns. Our production numbers have been on the rise, and the average number of industrial gas cylinders filled per day improved sequentially by 8% in the first quarter compared to the fourth quarter. Excluding fuel gases, which declined seasonally in our first quarter, sales per day for cylinder gases improved 4% from the fourth quarter. Regardless of the metric you'd pick, solid improvement in our underlying business is evident. 
Our sales and marketing strategy focused on segment alignment also continues to gain momentum. Success thus far has been most pronounced in our Strategic Accounts program, where this strategy originated and was already underway in Medical and Construction segments. 
For the first quarter, Strategic Accounts business was up 12% from the prior year, driven by new account signings across all customer segments and by increased activity in our existing metal fabrication and materials and conglomerates customer base. Strategic Accounts present tremendous cross-sell opportunities, both in terms of product line and locations and now represent 20% of the total sales. 
Turning to Slide 3, sales of our Strategic Products, which combines that make up over 40% of our revenue, increased 9% for the quarter, stronger than the overall same-store sales increase of 6%. Our Strategic Products as a group continue to have particularly good long-term growth profiles as many of our growth accelerators impact their performance.  
Safety Products sales grew 15% year-over-year in the quarter, comparing favorably to the overall Hardgoods same-store sales increase of 8%. On a sequential basis, daily sales of Safety Products were up 8%. The increase in Safety Products sales was broad based, although most pronounced at our manufacturing customer base as operating rates have steadily improved. Safety Products sales still represented strong cross-sell opportunities for us as our customer realize good value in vendor consolidation. 
Bulk Gas sales were up 8% compared to prior year and up 4% sequentially compared to the fourth quarter, as sales of bulk nitrogen for food-freezing application to continue to show strength supported by the launch of our FreezeRight line of cryogenic freezers, and bulk sales to industrial manufacturing customers continue to recover in segments such as Steel and Auto. 
Specialty Gas sales increased 7% year-over-year, driven largely by higher volumes. Sequentially, the Specialty Gas daily sales improved by 3%, driven by a broad-based increase in demand for core specialty gases, including further strengthening of our market position in EPA protocol and other calibration gas mixtures.
Our Radnor private label products were up 15% for the quarter, better than the same-store sales increase in total Hardgoods. The long-term growth opportunities for the Radnor brand remains strong. In addition to building brand loyalty within our customer base, gross margins on Radnor products are 1.5x or more than comparable OEM products. 
Our operating efficiency programs that's focused on cylinder maintenance testing, distribution of fill plant logistics, brake and fuel management are progressing according to schedule. At our December Analyst Meeting, we set a goal to attain $40 million of new operating efficiency savings over the next four years, driven largely by logistics, plant studies and cylinder testing. We are on track to deliver the $10 million of those savings that are included in our fiscal 2011 guidance. 
As planned, we've began the phase rollout of our highly customized SAP platform on July 5. Our Hardgoods distribution infrastructure, including our six national distribution centers, our national purchasing organization and the Safety telesales organizations were the first to go live, and thus far, the feedback has been very positive. Our next SAP rollout will be to one of our regional distribution companies later in fiscal 2011. 
The commencement of our plant phase rollout, whereby business units implement the new system in succession, marks a major milestone in the structural development of our company. As in everything we do, we have taken a customer-centric approach to SAP, planning and executing to minimize conversion risk and ensure a seamless transition for our customers. We expect returns that will more than justify our investments, significantly above our internal hurdle rate of 15% to 20% IRR and return on capital and well above our cost of capital. Given our expertise with system conversions and the amount of time and energy we've invested, we are uniquely positioned to maximize the value of this investment, and we are confident that the implementation of SAP will create meaningful value for all Airgas stockholders. 
Through June 2010, we have invested more than half of the total plant for the project. For fiscal 2011, we expect incremental operating expenses of approximately $14 million as we begin the implementation phase of the project, driven by training, conversion and depreciation. All SAP-related operating and implementation costs for the current implementation schedule are included in our midterm financial goals introduced in December 2009, but the benefits of our SAP implementation and the positive impact we expected to have on our financial results are not included in our forecast. 
Benefits will include customer phasing applications that will improve the customer's buying experience, assisted with cross selling and simplified account administration and enhanced feasibility for multi-location customers. We also expect significant gains and efficiencies in both the gases and hardgoods supply chain, as well as in administrator processing [ph]. In addition, SAP tools and functionality will drive more structured and disciplined pricing. As we move forward with SAP conversions, we will further refine the quantity and timing of the benefits we anticipate and update our midterm financial goals accordingly. 
Now Bob will give our financial review of the quarter.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to start today by reviewing our consolidated results. Please turn to Slide 4. As I go through these results, please note that we have GAAP reconciliations for various metrics on Slides 11 through 15. Sa
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to start today by reviewing our consolidated results. Please turn to Slide 4. As I go through these results, please note that we have GAAP reconciliations for various metrics on Slides 11 through 15. 
Sales increased by 7% year-over-year to a little over $1 billion, reflecting acquisition growth of 1% and total same-store sales growth of 6%, comprised of the 5% increase in Gas and Rent and an 8% increase in Hardgoods. Volume was up 5% and price was up 1%, with only one month of contribution from the June price increase. 
Sequentially, sales increased by 7%, driven by an incremental selling day and a 5% sequential increase in daily sales. Both Hardgoods and Gas and Rent sales improved sequentially on a daily sales basis, with Gas and Rent leading the way, up 6%. Consistent with the fourth quarter, Gas and Rent represented approximately 64% of our sales mix. The Gas and Rent mix was slightly higher in the first quarter of last year at 65%. 
Gross margin was 54.9%, a decline of 40 basis points from the prior year, primarily reflecting the expected sales mix shift towards lower-margin hardgoods that is characteristic of an industrial economic recovery. Sequentially, however, gross margin expanded by 50 basis points reflecting seasonal rebound of certain businesses in the All Other Operations segment, which I will discuss on the next slide. 
Excluding pretax charges of approximately $4 million related to Air Products' unsolicited takeover attempt and approximately $3 million related to the withdrawal from multi-employer pension plan, adjusted operating income for the quarter was $130 million, up 20% from last year and up 24% sequentially from the fourth quarter. Adjusted operating margin was 12.3%, a 130 basis-point improvement over the prior year and 160 basis-point improvement sequentially, driven by operating leverage on sales growth in the quarter, which more than overcame sequential and year-over-year expense headwinds from variable compensation resets and the SAP implementation. 
Adjusted earnings per diluted share were $0.83 in the first quarter, a 26% increase from the prior year and a 20% increase on a sequential basis. This quarter marked the second highest earnings performance in our history, the highest being $0.86 in September 2008 quarter, just prior to the economic downturn. 
There were approximately 85 million weighted-average diluted shares outstanding for the quarter, up about 2% year-over-year and up 1% on a sequential basis. Return on capital, which is a trailing four-quarters calculation, was 10.5%, a 130 basis-point decline from the prior year, primarily driven by the recession and the related decline in operating income. Sequentially, however, return on capital improved by 50 basis points on the strength of our improved operating income this quarter. 
Turning now to Slide 5, we look at our segment results. Distribution sales in the quarter were up 7% versus the prior year to $932 million, with same-store sales up 5%. Gas and Rent same-store sales were up 3%, and were up 8%, with pricing up 1% in both categories, impacted in part by one-month contribution from our June 1 price increase. 
On a sequential basis, distribution sales increased 5%, driven by a 3% increase in daily sales rate and an incremental selling day. Both Hardgoods and Gas and Rent sales improved sequentially on a daily basis, with Hardgoods up 4%, slightly outpacing Gas and Rent. This is the third consecutive quarter that we have seen our daily distribution rates increase, with a slight acceleration of that pace in this quarter. And as both Mike and Peter highlighted, we are clearly seeing signs that our business is gaining momentum. 
Distribution gross margin was 55.5%, a decrease of 60 basis points in the prior year, primarily reflecting the expected sales mix shift toward lower-margin hardgoods. Sequentially, distribution gross margin improved 20 basis points. Consistent with the fourth quarter, Gas and Rent represented close to 50% of distribution sales in the first quarter. 
Adjusted operating income in the Distribution segment increased 19% year-over-year to $107 million. Sequentially, adjusted operating income improved to $107 million from $100 million in the fourth quarter. It's worth highlighting that we achieved that strong sequential improvement in adjusted operating income after overcoming approximately $14 million in sequential expense hurdles, including post-recession reset of variable compensation and stock-based compensation expense, which is front-end loaded in our fiscal year due to retiree eligible vesting provisions. 
Adjusted operating margin in the Distribution segment expanded sequentially for a fourth consecutive quarter to 11.5%. All Other Operations reflects our CO2, Dry Ice, Refrigerants, Ammonia and Nitrous Oxide business units. Sales for All Other Operations were up 14% in total and 13% on a same-store sales basis from the prior year, driven largely by a strong performance in our Refrigerants business this quarter. 
The Refrigerants business benefited from some pent-up demand, as well as certain products shortages, and we were able to leverage our broad platform to respond where other suppliers could not, generating both volume and margin expansion. Sequentially, the sales improvement was driven by seasonal improvement in the Refrigerants, CO2 and Dry Ice businesses, as well as by the strong performance in Refrigerants. 
Operating income for All Other Operations was $23 million. Operating margin increased by 150 basis points year-over-year, as margin compression in the Ammonia business resulting from rising cost was more than offset by margin expansion in the Refrigerants business. Sequentially, the more than 1,200-basis-point improvement in operating margin is primarily attributable to the normal seasonal improvement in the CO2 and Dry Ice businesses, which carry higher fixed cost than our Distribution businesses, as well as the strong performance in Refrigerants for the first quarter. 
With respect to accounts receivable, our collection rates for the quarter have remained relatively consistent, both year-over-year and sequentially, and our quarterly DSO of 47 days was slightly better than the fourth quarter's results. Inventory turns held consistent with recent trends, reflecting our disciplined management of inventory levels during the significant uptick in hardgoods sales. 
We generated strong free cash flow for the quarter of $130 million driven by adjusted cash from operations of $171 million. The strength of our robust earnings, continued strong cash flow and outlook for the future, we increased our second quarter dividend by 14% to $0.25 per share. We have reduced adjusted debt by approximately $83 million in the first quarter to $1.7 billion at June 30 and reduced it by over $260 million on a year-over-year basis. Our fixed-float ratio at the end of June was about 52% fixed, and our adjusted debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 2.6, within our revised target range of two to three. 
Please turn to Slide 6, capital expenditures. We have continued to be disciplined in our capital spending this year, which was down 9% in the quarter versus the prior year, as we lapped the completion of our new ASU in Kentucky that was completed last year. CapEx represented 5.8% of sales, consistent with our expectation.
Slide 7 presents our fiscal 2011 second quarter and updated full year guidance. For the second quarter, we expect earnings per share to be in the range of $0.78 to $0.82, an increase of 15% to 21% over the prior year and including $0.03 of incremental SAP implementation costs. Excluding incremental SAP costs, our guidance represents a 19% to 25% improvement over the prior year. For the full year, we are raising our earnings per share expectations to be in the range of $3.15 to $3.30, up 18% to 23% over adjusted earnings per share for fiscal 2010 and including $0.10 of incremental SAP implementation costs. Excluding incremental SAP costs, our guidance for the full year reflects a 21% to 27% improvement over fiscal 2010. We expect same-store sales growth to be in the high single digits in the second quarter and in the mid- to upper-single digits for the full fiscal year. Our guidance range does include SAP expense. 
Operating margins are now expected to be in the 12% to 12.5% range, and we continue to estimate capital expenditures to be approximately 5.5% of sales. We expect our tax rate to be in the range of 38% to 39%, and our guidance does not incorporate the impact of debt extinguishment, multi-employer pension plan withdrawal charges or costs related to the unsolicited takeover attempt. 
Slide 8 presents a walk through the primary elements of our guidance using first quarter adjusted EPS of $0.83 and fiscal 2010 adjusted EPS of $2.68 as the starting points for the second quarter and full year respectively. Sequentially, the second quarter has headwinds of approximately $0.06 driven by seasonality, in addition to strong first quarter performance in our Refrigerants business, seasonality in the Rental Welder business and incremental SAP implementation expense. 
We expect the four business to expand sequentially 1% to 6%, with price tailwinds that overcome the normal seasonal flowing in July and early August in our core Distribution business. For the full year, our updated $3.15 to $3.30 guidance reflects headwinds from variable compensation reset, SAP implementation, tax rate and share count, which is more than offset by a 27% to 33% improvement in the underlying business, driven by continued momentum in our sales growth, our price increase initiative and operating efficiencies. The guidance also reflects the normal third and fourth quarter seasonal slowing in our CO2, Dry Ice and Refrigerants businesses. 
The underlying business improvement is consistent with the plan we developed in conjunction with our midterm financial goals we announced at the December Analyst Meeting. And in fact, our trajectory is higher. And now I'll turn it back to Peter.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Before we go to Q&A, I want to quickly highlight some of the reasons that underscore our confidence in Airgas' prospects for continued growth and shareholder value creation. Slide 9 illustrates the EPS growth generated in the economic recov
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Before we go to Q&A, I want to quickly highlight some of the reasons that underscore our confidence in Airgas' prospects for continued growth and shareholder value creation. 
Slide 9 illustrates the EPS growth generated in the economic recovery from calendar 2002 to 2005 and contrast that with the growth represented by our current midterm goals. In the three-year period following the last recession, we delivered a compound annual EPS growth rate of 18%. Our earnings growth tend to accelerate as an expansion continues, particularly after overcoming the initial headwinds of variable costs at the outset of recovery. We announced a new set of midterm financial goals at our December Analyst Meeting, consistent with our practice over the last decade. We are proud of our proven track record of meeting or exceeding our targets. The bottom chart shows the earnings growth trajectory from calendar 2009 to our calendar 2012 target of $4.20 per share or greater. The 16% CAGR is more conservative than our performance in the last recovery in spite of the fact that we are a much stronger operating company today. 
Attractive upside could come from a cooperative economy and/or the benefits of our SAP implementation. You can clearly see that our revised fiscal 2011 guidance range is above the earnings trajectory on which these current midterm goals are built, a point which Bob just made. In other words, if we continue at our current pace, I expect us to beat our target of $4.20 per share for calendar 2012. We point these factors out to underscore our board's view that we're confident we can deliver superior value to our stockholders by continuing to execute our strategic plan. 
Finally, I want to be clear that there is tremendous opportunity for Airgas stockholders to benefit from the future value of the execution of our business strategies, as highlighted on Slide 10. Our industry is still very fragmented, and acquisitions are our core competency at Airgas. The benefits of our customer-centric culture and new sales alignment are just starting to develop. And on the subject of alignment, between the Airgas board and the management team, we own 12% of the company so that the interest of the Airgas board and management are aligned with those of all Airgas stockholders. 
We appreciate the tremendous amount of support we've received from our shareholders and look forward to continuing to deliver outstanding value to you in the years to come. Thank you. And now I'd like to turn it back to Jay for Q&A.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: That concludes our prepared remarks.  [Operator Instructions] Jennifer will now give instructions for asking questions.
componenttext: That concludes our prepared remarks.  [Operator Instructions] Jennifer will now give instructions for asking questions.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Laurence Alexander of Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Laurence Alexander of Jefferies.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Lucy Watson on for Laurence today. I just wanted to start with a couple of questions on the 2012 outlook, if I may. Are you factoring any economic improvements into that $4.20 number? And if so, would it be possible to quantify the growth you migh
componenttext: This is Lucy Watson on for Laurence today. I just wanted to start with a couple of questions on the 2012 outlook, if I may. Are you factoring any economic improvements into that $4.20 number? And if so, would it be possible to quantify the growth you might be expecting?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: In our model, we assume 2% to 2.5% of GDP non-tech industrial production as the baseline assumption. It's averaged over that period of time.
componenttext: In our model, we assume 2% to 2.5% of GDP non-tech industrial production as the baseline assumption. It's averaged over that period of time.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then how much capital expenditures are required to get to that earnings level?
componenttext: And then how much capital expenditures are required to get to that earnings level?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We roughly have approximately 5% to 5.5% built into the forecast with respect to capital expenditures. And that, as a backdrop of approximately 3% to slightly under 3%, would be our maintenance CapEx.
componenttext: We roughly have approximately 5% to 5.5% built into the forecast with respect to capital expenditures. And that, as a backdrop of approximately 3% to slightly under 3%, would be our maintenance CapEx.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then you mentioned that there are a couple of regions, I guess, where you haven't yet seen improvement. Would you mind providing a little bit more color?
componenttext: And then you mentioned that there are a couple of regions, I guess, where you haven't yet seen improvement. Would you mind providing a little bit more color?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, recoveries usually began in the heartland of the country and the manufacturing districts, which are the upper Midwest. Our Great Lakes region is one that I mentioned in my portion of the presentation. The South also, and then the Coast tend to lag.
componenttext: Well, recoveries usually began in the heartland of the country and the manufacturing districts, which are the upper Midwest. Our Great Lakes region is one that I mentioned in my portion of the presentation. The South also, and then the Coast tend to lag. And the West lags a little bit although we're very strong in Texas right now. I would say that this looks like a normal recovery. All of our regions are doing much better. It's just the real outperformance is coming in the manufacturing regions, especially Great Lakes. But we expect the recovery will continue the normal path and that the Coast will improve as we move through.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We move next to Mike Harrison of First Analysis.
componenttext: We move next to Mike Harrison of First Analysis.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask you about the All Other segment and the operating income improvement sequentially. You saw about $17 million or so in operating income improvement. Can you quantify or give us any sense of how much of that improvement came from the Refrigera
componenttext: Wanted to ask you about the All Other segment and the operating income improvement sequentially. You saw about $17 million or so in operating income improvement. Can you quantify or give us any sense of how much of that improvement came from the Refrigerants business, which it sounds like was much stronger? What you saw in terms of any change in Ammonia cost and how that impacted your operating income? How much you got from seasonal mix improvement, how much from operating leverage? And any other factors that were in play in that business?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, most of our outperformance this quarter came from our core business. We did very well though in the other off-section part of our business. Refrigerants was the primary driver there. Actually, year-over-year, Ammonia profitability was down somewhat
componenttext: Well, most of our outperformance this quarter came from our core business. We did very well though in the other off-section part of our business. Refrigerants was the primary driver there. Actually, year-over-year, Ammonia profitability was down somewhat because we had the high prices in the prior year, which was sort of an extraordinary situation. But net-net, I'd say, most of the improvement came from our core business, which is pretty good when you consider we had to overcome some significant headwinds with variable compensation and stock-based compensation. So regarding Refrigerants, so there was terrific performance. And Mike, would you want to comment on how we're doing overall in Refrigerants?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, I've talked with many of you since we acquired the Refrigerants businesses that we have used to combine to make Airgas refrigerants. And up until recently, Refrigerants was somewhat disappointing because the demand had declined so much in the coun
componenttext: I mean, I've talked with many of you since we acquired the Refrigerants businesses that we have used to combine to make Airgas refrigerants. And up until recently, Refrigerants was somewhat disappointing because the demand had declined so much in the country during recession. So I think we've just now begun to see the type of performance that we're expecting from Refrigerants going forward. And it's an area where many of the products are now regulated. Production is regulated and is reduced, and it's all going to rely on having the right inventories and the right places and reclamation and all of the things that we have been investing in for the past several years that is just now starting to bear fruit. So I continue to be very excited about the prospects for our Refrigerants business going forward.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: You feel like going forward, Mike, that you can continue to put up this kind of performance in Refrigerants or does it slow down a little bit from this?
componenttext: You feel like going forward, Mike, that you can continue to put up this kind of performance in Refrigerants or does it slow down a little bit from this?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Refrigerants is a very seasonal business, okay? So if I was to look year-over-year, quarter-over-quarter, I would say, yes. If I look at the sequential quarters as I move to the end of the summer and the colder months, I would say there's going to b
componenttext: Well, Refrigerants is a very seasonal business, okay? So if I was to look year-over-year, quarter-over-quarter, I would say, yes. If I look at the sequential quarters as I move to the end of the summer and the colder months, I would say there's going to be some seasonal changes. But overall, the prospects for us in Refrigerants, with all other things we have been investing in and positioning ourselves to take advantage of, are excellent.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Last question I had was on the Strategic Accounts business. In terms of your expanded efforts there and expanding into some new customer segments, where are you seeing the greatest gains in terms of that expanded effort? And where might you still be a lit
componenttext: Last question I had was on the Strategic Accounts business. In terms of your expanded efforts there and expanding into some new customer segments, where are you seeing the greatest gains in terms of that expanded effort? And where might you still be a little bit disappointed or maybe you're still in the earlier stages of revamping the sales and marketing efforts?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just say -- I'll answer it now, let Mike have a shot at it. I'm seeing the greatest gains in productivity because we have assigned people to each customer segments. They're very familiar with these customer segments, and we're being very thor
componenttext: Well, let me just say -- I'll answer it now, let Mike have a shot at it. I'm seeing the greatest gains in productivity because we have assigned people to each customer segments. They're very familiar with these customer segments, and we're being very thorough in our approaches to all important customers in those segments. We're also seeing a lot of benefit from penetration of existing Strategic Accounts. That is, where we have an account, we've had it for three years, but we only had 65% of the locations implemented for a number of reasons. And we're pressing hard for full implementation and having good results. The third area I would say is cross-selling. We want to sell all of our products and services to these companies, and there are many of these Strategic Accounts that only buy one or two products from us. So we're having great success in improving that. And then the signings have been terrific now for three quarters in a row. And I'll let Mike talk about the organization and what he think.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, first thing to clarify is that there are no new customer segments that we have not been selling into that we started. I mean, we are just trying to be much more effective in penetrating the segments that we have always participated in with varying ex
componenttext: Yes, first thing to clarify is that there are no new customer segments that we have not been selling into that we started. I mean, we are just trying to be much more effective in penetrating the segments that we have always participated in with varying extents. And I think, Peter's comments are right on because what we're trying to do is the needs of the chemical industry are very different than what the energy sector people want, which are very different than what the large metal fabrication and steel people want. And being able to take our full portfolio of products to each of those segments tailored to really maximize the value we can bring them in has already started to pay tremendous dividends, and we've got a long runway to drive that yet.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I would also add that we have a little wind at our backs. When you have an economic period like we just went through in this country, customers get very religious about supply chain management. And Airgas has an outstanding value proposition in terms of t
componenttext: I would also add that we have a little wind at our backs. When you have an economic period like we just went through in this country, customers get very religious about supply chain management. And Airgas has an outstanding value proposition in terms of the breadth of its product and service offering and the supply chain services that we can deliver. So we've had a lot of interest from customers as well, and that's helping.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll move on to Deutsche Bank's David Begleiter.
componenttext: We'll move on to Deutsche Bank's David Begleiter.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Peter, on the June 1 price increase, in terms of the gases, how much of the 69% are you getting have you gotten and where that stand?
componenttext: Peter, on the June 1 price increase, in terms of the gases, how much of the 69% are you getting have you gotten and where that stand?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The price increase was -- sorry, the effective date was June 1. I would say it's very successful from my vantage point. We will get the full benefit of that price increase in the second quarter. We hadn't had a price increase for two years, and we held of
componenttext: The price increase was -- sorry, the effective date was June 1. I would say it's very successful from my vantage point. We will get the full benefit of that price increase in the second quarter. We hadn't had a price increase for two years, and we held off even though some of our costs had been increasing because of the state of the economy. And we got to the point where we felt that we were justified, and we executed very well. Mike, you might want to chime in on the price increase.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, when all is said and done, we would expect that we would realize probably at least 3% yield on the increase.
componenttext: Yes, I mean, when all is said and done, we would expect that we would realize probably at least 3% yield on the increase.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So Mike, just to be clear, you announced 6% to 9%, so you're expecting of that to get half of that or a third of that?
componenttext: So Mike, just to be clear, you announced 6% to 9%, so you're expecting of that to get half of that or a third of that?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, depending -- you're not going to get the price from everyone. There's different contractual terms. There's all the types of dynamics that play into that. But when all is said and done, as we track the results, which we do very closely, we wou
componenttext: Yes, I mean, depending -- you're not going to get the price from everyone. There's different contractual terms. There's all the types of dynamics that play into that. But when all is said and done, as we track the results, which we do very closely, we would expect to wind up with at least a 3% yield on our overall gas and rental revenues.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, is that typical of price increases where you don't realize a full announced level?
componenttext: Mike, is that typical of price increases where you don't realize a full announced level?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely.
componenttext: Absolutely.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Peter, versus December's meeting, what's changed in your expectations of Airgas' future prospects and earnings power?
componenttext: Peter, versus December's meeting, what's changed in your expectations of Airgas' future prospects and earnings power?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we still have all those growth accelerators going. In fact, they're actually doing better than we thought. We emerged from this economy with a lot of strength. We thought we would, but even I was surprised. We've achieved really good margins for bei
componenttext: Well, we still have all those growth accelerators going. In fact, they're actually doing better than we thought. We emerged from this economy with a lot of strength. We thought we would, but even I was surprised. We've achieved really good margins for being so early in the recovery, and that shows the cost discipline that we've had. It reflects good execution on our price increase. I am very pleased. I couldn't, back in December, I couldn't see as clearly the benefits of our reorganization of our national accounts group along customer segment lines. And that is going very, very well. On the SAP front, we have started our implementation. Knock on wood, it's going very well. That was three years of very hard work and a lot of planning by a terrific team. And we're looking forward to moving forward with our total implementation plan. And remember, our guidance for calendar '12 has all of the SAP costs and none of the benefits. And we're, hopefully, we're going to be in a position in the not-too-distant future to give some range of benefits and some idea of what SAP is going to look like at Airgas and what impact it might have. And we're working on that now. And I would say, interest rates have been favorable. That helped us $0.01 in the quarter, I think, and then better than planned. And I just keep coming back to we run this company for the long term, and we try to do the right things for the long term. And every time we emerge from a recession, we come out stronger. And this time is a fine example of that.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll move next to Mike Sison of KeyBanc.
componenttext: We'll move next to Mike Sison of KeyBanc.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Peter, you've commented to some degree that you felt your $4.20 goal for '12 seems conservative. Can you sort of highlight some of the areas where you think the conservatism could lie? Is it maybe what you can do in terms of growth? Does it include full b
componenttext: Peter, you've commented to some degree that you felt your $4.20 goal for '12 seems conservative. Can you sort of highlight some of the areas where you think the conservatism could lie? Is it maybe what you can do in terms of growth? Does it include full benefits of SAP or maybe acquisitions? You haven't really talked about how acquisitions can help out.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, to be clear, I didn't call it conservative. I said, and Bob said, that we're on a trajectory that would take us above that. And I personally expect that we can beat it. But anyway, yes, I mean, we're assuming a modest -- the continuation of a modest
componenttext: Well, to be clear, I didn't call it conservative. I said, and Bob said, that we're on a trajectory that would take us above that. And I personally expect that we can beat it. But anyway, yes, I mean, we're assuming a modest -- the continuation of a modest economic recovery. A stronger economy would certainly help us. SAP could help us a little bit. It's not going to be a major factor in calendar year '12. And I really can't answer that now, but there may be some minor benefits from that. I think continued strong execution by our team, Strategic Accounts, they're growing quickly again, they have a great history. Strategic Products, they're growing again faster than the overall company. We've invested a huge amount of money in the last two or three years in air separation plants, in our three  refrigerant acquisitions to make Airgas refrigerants and upgraded fill plants and things like that. And I think we're going to see the benefits of those investments, and there could be some upside there. I don't know. Mike, do you see anything else?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, typically, as we go through the recovery, we start to see inflation, which is going to help us with pricing environment. We have air separation plants that have a lot of unlevered capacity. That's going to benefit us. In the last three years
componenttext: Well, I mean, typically, as we go through the recovery, we start to see inflation, which is going to help us with pricing environment. We have air separation plants that have a lot of unlevered capacity. That's going to benefit us. In the last three years, we've dramatically increased our sourcing efforts for our Radnor products, which is going to continue to reduce our cost of securing Radnor products. I mean, you can take pretty much any line you want to take. And we've got several things going on that's going to help add value.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Right. You know, Mike's point on inflation, inflation is good for our business because our assets don't wear out and we're able to get price. And if that comes, on the other hand, we've managed and served at deflationary environment fairly well. So any wa
componenttext: Right. You know, Mike's point on inflation, inflation is good for our business because our assets don't wear out and we're able to get price. And if that comes, on the other hand, we've managed and served at deflationary environment fairly well. So any way it comes, we're ready for it. I guess that's about it.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when you take a look at your outlook for fiscal '11, the $3.15 to $3.30, what are the particular drivers that get you to the upper end versus the lower end of that outlook?
componenttext: Okay. And then when you take a look at your outlook for fiscal '11, the $3.15 to $3.30, what are the particular drivers that get you to the upper end versus the lower end of that outlook?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, continuation of the economic recovery, we can't have this stall in a big way. We're not looking for a gangbusters economy, but continuation of this modest improvement that we've seen, I think, is a big factor; continued cost discipline. One thing I
componenttext: Well, continuation of the economic recovery, we can't have this stall in a big way. We're not looking for a gangbusters economy, but continuation of this modest improvement that we've seen, I think, is a big factor; continued cost discipline. One thing I didn't mention as a factor, neither Mike nor I mentioned, was our efficiency programs. We continue to find new ways to take costs out of the system. We've been very successful. We're going to find new ways. We now have a real estate management program that's yielding terrific results. And in terms of rationalizing excess real estate, reducing rentals, reducing taxes, things like that. So outperformance on the cost side could certainly be a factor going forward here. Bob, what do you see?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: All those, Peter. And plus, as we talked about the price increase, there could be some upside as it relates to the 3% assumption we put on that as well. So the leveraging of the expenses is tremendous. We're at our record level on EBITDA margin and almost
componenttext: All those, Peter. And plus, as we talked about the price increase, there could be some upside as it relates to the 3% assumption we put on that as well. So the leveraging of the expenses is tremendous. We're at our record level on EBITDA margin and almost at a record level of operating margin in our first quarter out. So that bodes well for what we see in the horizon here.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Moving on to Kevin McCarthy of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Moving on to Kevin McCarthy of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: If I look back over the past decade, Peter, Airgas' EPS has usually increased in the fiscal second quarter versus the first, and in the worst years, it's held flat. And so as I look at your guidance of $0.78 to $0.82 here, just down slightly sequentially,
componenttext: If I look back over the past decade, Peter, Airgas' EPS has usually increased in the fiscal second quarter versus the first, and in the worst years, it's held flat. And so as I look at your guidance of $0.78 to $0.82 here, just down slightly sequentially, I was hoping you could help me understand what might be driving that pattern. For example, on Slide 8, you indicate Refrigerants and Rental Welders could be a $0.05 headwind sequentially. Is that a greater-than-normal seasonal headwinds that you would anticipate?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're going to have more seasonality in the Refrigerants business now, now that we have really good Refrigerants business. Our second quarter in Refrigerants will be good, but we don't expect it to be as good as the first quarter because of seasonal
componenttext: Well, we're going to have more seasonality in the Refrigerants business now, now that we have really good Refrigerants business. Our second quarter in Refrigerants will be good, but we don't expect it to be as good as the first quarter because of seasonality. So that's certainly one factor in that. And I would say -- what other...

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: On the Rental Welder side, there's also some additional challenges with the European business that we have that's further behind from an economic standpoint than the U.S. So that's creating a little bit more of an anomaly in the headwind this time around.
componenttext: On the Rental Welder side, there's also some additional challenges with the European business that we have that's further behind from an economic standpoint than the U.S. So that's creating a little bit more of an anomaly in the headwind this time around. And as Peter mentioned, the seasonality, we did have a very strong performance in Q1 with respect to Refrigerants. So those two factors.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The Red-D-Arc business is mostly a North American business, and it's mostly driven by Energy business and Non-Res Construction. And the Non-Res Construction business has been pretty bad. But I'm happy to report that Red-D-Arc and our Construction group ar
componenttext: The Red-D-Arc business is mostly a North American business, and it's mostly driven by Energy business and Non-Res Construction. And the Non-Res Construction business has been pretty bad. But I'm happy to report that Red-D-Arc and our Construction group are reporting somewhat of a comeback this fall in the Non-Res Construction outages and some major projects. So that's been hurting us. But most of that is going to impact the third quarter, Kevin, and just sort of the end of the second quarter.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It just struck me as perhaps a little bit conservative given your outlook for high single-digit same-store sales growth in 2Q. A second question, if I may. If I look at Slide 4, you indicate that the daily sales rate increased 5% sequentially for the quar
componenttext: It just struck me as perhaps a little bit conservative given your outlook for high single-digit same-store sales growth in 2Q. A second question, if I may. If I look at Slide 4, you indicate that the daily sales rate increased 5% sequentially for the quarter. Would you elaborate on how that DSR metric would've fluctuated as the quarter progressed from April through June?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Fairly improved in June, and that was benefited from the price increase that was initiated in June. So it's progressed fairly steadily as we moved through the quarter.
componenttext: Fairly improved in June, and that was benefited from the price increase that was initiated in June. So it's progressed fairly steadily as we moved through the quarter.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And what are you seeing in early July relative to the June level?
componenttext: Okay. And what are you seeing in early July relative to the June level?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: As I mentioned, we see a continuation. There's a little slowdown because we started the month with a July 4 holiday. But everything that we can see is that July is continuing at June levels, with the exception of that seasonality or holiday thing.
componenttext: As I mentioned, we see a continuation. There's a little slowdown because we started the month with a July 4 holiday. But everything that we can see is that July is continuing at June levels, with the exception of that seasonality or holiday thing.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Piper Jaffray's Tom Hayes.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Piper Jaffray's Tom Hayes.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could just remind us of the operating margin assumptions associated with the calendar year $4.20 target.
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could just remind us of the operating margin assumptions associated with the calendar year $4.20 target.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, same-store sales, I think, are 7%; EBITDA margin, 18% to 18.5%, and we're already within that range. I mean, this quarter was in that range and continuation of our efficiency programs.
componenttext: Okay. Well, same-store sales, I think, are 7%; EBITDA margin, 18% to 18.5%, and we're already within that range. I mean, this quarter was in that range and continuation of our efficiency programs.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Same-store sales around 7% average over that period.
componenttext: Same-store sales around 7% average over that period.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Previously announced efficiency programs.

componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up to -- Mike, and if you mentioned it, I apologize, what were the results for Radnor for the quarter for the sequential and year-over-year basis?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: 15% year-over-year.
componenttext: 15% year-over-year.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll hear next from Mark Gulley of Soleil Securities.
componenttext: We'll hear next from Mark Gulley of Soleil Securities.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: First question regards CapEx, with sales growth increasing, I'm a little surprised to see CapEx still down. And maybe, Bob, while you've talked about your guidance for the year, when would CapEx to sales have to accelerate to accommodate the better sales
componenttext: First question regards CapEx, with sales growth increasing, I'm a little surprised to see CapEx still down. And maybe, Bob, while you've talked about your guidance for the year, when would CapEx to sales have to accelerate to accommodate the better sales growth?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we think we're comfortable with that. Relative to the same-store sales growth of 7% that we project on the horizon, the 5.5% that I mentioned, we're comfortable with. A lot of the years that we've exceeded that significantly were related to doing bu
componenttext: Well, we think we're comfortable with that. Relative to the same-store sales growth of 7% that we project on the horizon, the 5.5% that I mentioned, we're comfortable with. A lot of the years that we've exceeded that significantly were related to doing business combination, consolidation, building ASUs, building the CO2 plant, et cetera. So relative to what we have factored into our projection, we're very comfortable with that mid-5% relative to as a percent of sales.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Secondly, talking about acquisitions, clearly, a big engine for growth historically, the pace of acquisitions has fairly slowed for some time now. Is that because sellers don't want to sell off of soft LTM numbers? Is it because they're concerned ab
componenttext: Okay. Secondly, talking about acquisitions, clearly, a big engine for growth historically, the pace of acquisitions has fairly slowed for some time now. Is that because sellers don't want to sell off of soft LTM numbers? Is it because they're concerned about this takeover bid? Can you give us a flavor, Peter, for what's holding back the pace of acquisitions?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm sure that the takeover bid is clouding the picture for some sellers. But we're still the acquirer of choice in this industry. And most people who have good companies would like to see them in good hands, and we've been the market leader here. So
componenttext: Well, I'm sure that the takeover bid is clouding the picture for some sellers. But we're still the acquirer of choice in this industry. And most people who have good companies would like to see them in good hands, and we've been the market leader here. So I continue to believe that the major factor in the slowness in acquisitions is the seller's unwilling to sell a company right near the trough of the recession or only four months into a recovery. It's a stupid thing to do and they have the cash flow and don't need to do it, so they wait for a year into the recovery or a year and a half, and that's when they sell. And we have some increased activity going on now. And it's not gangbusters, but it's an uptick in activity, and maybe we're starting to see a little bit of that yet. But it's certainly not robust, and I wouldn't expect it to be until these companies could put up some higher numbers.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then finally, you're on the front lines of selling a lot of stuff to industrial customers. The media is full of concerns about a double dip. What is your observation? Are those concerns overblown or what?
componenttext: And then finally, you're on the front lines of selling a lot of stuff to industrial customers. The media is full of concerns about a double dip. What is your observation? Are those concerns overblown or what?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not an economist like some people I have heard about. But I run a company that's a good mirror on the overall economy. We have an extremely diverse customer base, and we're seeing broad strength across all customer segments. And even Non-Res Con
componenttext: Well, I'm not an economist like some people I have heard about. But I run a company that's a good mirror on the overall economy. We have an extremely diverse customer base, and we're seeing broad strength across all customer segments. And even Non-Res Construction, which was really, really down, we're seeing a comeback late summer or fall. And I'm not suggesting it's gangbusters, but it's a heck of a lot better than it was. So we're seeing the strength across all customer segments, and we see business spending money, investing capital, making CapEx. That's helpful to us, and we're taking advantage of it.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So it sounds like you think those concerns are overblown.
componenttext: So it sounds like you think those concerns are overblown.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, residential housing, restaurants, Hermès scarves, those things don't really do a lot for our business. We're a business-to-business company, and American businesses seem to be pretty healthy. They have a lot of cash. Our accounts receivable is heal
componenttext: Well, residential housing, restaurants, Hermès scarves, those things don't really do a lot for our business. We're a business-to-business company, and American businesses seem to be pretty healthy. They have a lot of cash. Our accounts receivable is healthy, and we're actually seeing some phenomenon called onshoring, where American businesses are bringing back factories to the United States that were overseas, and we're seeing new facilities being built in the United States. And we find that pretty encouraging.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Our next question comes from David Manthey of Robert W. Baird.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Peter, I was wondering if you could talk about two end markets, specifically Construction and Maintenance. I know on the Construction side, you're more technical rather than office and retail, specifically. And I also know that a while back, you were opti
componenttext: Peter, I was wondering if you could talk about two end markets, specifically Construction and Maintenance. I know on the Construction side, you're more technical rather than office and retail, specifically. And I also know that a while back, you were optimistic about the hospital build-out, for example, and I was wondering if you could just give us an update there. And on the Maintenance side, if you're seeing any pent-up demand being released from turnaround on Maintenance projects that were delayed or deferred previously?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're seeing a lot of the latter. There's no question about it. Companies waited a long time, and now a lot of these outage projects are being scheduled for late summer and fall. So we expect a very strong outage season. And in terms of Non-Res Cons
componenttext: Well, we're seeing a lot of the latter. There's no question about it. Companies waited a long time, and now a lot of these outage projects are being scheduled for late summer and fall. So we expect a very strong outage season. And in terms of Non-Res Construction, a lot of it is that, but there are other projects. Like, there's just been four natural gas pipelines announced, and we're pleased to be serving the contractors on those jobs and other kinds of coal power plants and other things that were delayed during the recession. The normal Maintenance customers, that business stayed pretty steady throughout the recession, distinguishing that from the outage work. Mike, do you have any color on the Construction?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think you portrayed it well. The big upside is, we see it coming is in turnarounds, rebuild, things like that. There are some big new projects that are individual and that will be exciting for us. And on the medical arena, I think we continue to pur
componenttext: No, I think you portrayed it well. The big upside is, we see it coming is in turnarounds, rebuild, things like that. There are some big new projects that are individual and that will be exciting for us. And on the medical arena, I think we continue to pursue that offering. We're just doing more and more in the offering of certification services to support the medical customer. And it's not that big, but it's a high value to customers.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: And I didn't answer your question about the hospital build-out, and that's certainly been delayed because hospital financing has been suffering. But we expect that to happen. It's just a matter of time. And we do see the build-out of a lot of small clinics near where people live, and that generates some good business for us and new good permanent customers.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, year-over-year, there was probably a $5 million benefit on the operating income line. But as you may recall, if you were following us, we had a very strong Ammonia in the first quarter of last year. So on balance, as we look at this All Other Operat
componenttext: Well, year-over-year, there was probably a $5 million benefit on the operating income line. But as you may recall, if you were following us, we had a very strong Ammonia in the first quarter of last year. So on balance, as we look at this All Other Operations segment, the one thing I would point out is, operating income, it's up 25% year-over-year from $18 million to $23 million; and our Distribution, which is 90% of the business, was up 19%. So it's really not that much out of proportion. Where we had a much stronger Refrigerant performance this year than last year, we had a weaker Ammonia performance. And as we said, these businesses tend to be more cyclical than our mainline core Distribution business, and we're going to have some ups and downs. But we're pretty pleased with the Refrigerants; also grew as a result of our regional companies embracing it and starting to cross sell. So we do think that there's strong momentum in the business. It should be there next year.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: The first thing, I guess, again, on your $4.20, I guess you've answered most of this, but I think in the past, you were talking about M&A being a part of sort of the top line expectation and helping to drive that $4.20. Are we at the point now where that $4.20 becomes possible just on base operations without any contribution from M&As that becomes sort of gravy? Or are we still assuming some level of M&A in that $4.20 number?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the $4.20 did have $150 million in the year in acquired sales. And given our trajectory right now, if this continues, we could make that without those acquisitions or most of those acquisitions, and they could be gravy on top of it. So we're pretty
componenttext: Well, the $4.20 did have $150 million in the year in acquired sales. And given our trajectory right now, if this continues, we could make that without those acquisitions or most of those acquisitions, and they could be gravy on top of it. So we're pretty excited to be doing this well so early in the recovery to have been able to execute on a good price increase and to be able to generate high margins early on. I think it bodes well. And we have a great track record of meeting our midterm financial goals.

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Okay. And then sort of I guess also in terms of getting to those types of numbers, in Q1, you put up sort of an incremental margin in the neighborhood of 30%. That's a number that I really don't think that you've matched or really come close to matching in the past periods or any period of time. Are you able to achieve that number largely because there's not a lot of M&A in the model right now? Or do you feel that the model is different in such a way that those incremental margins this time around will be greater than they were in the past? And sort of what were those pieces?

headline: Airgas Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you make a very good point. You get much more fall through when you don't have the background noise of M&A. And same-store sales versus acquired sales generate much higher profits. But our first quarter results are a function of a lot of things comi
componenttext: Well, you make a very good point. You get much more fall through when you don't have the background noise of M&A. And same-store sales versus acquired sales generate much higher profits. But our first quarter results are a function of a lot of things coming together at one time. The economic recovery certainly gained a bunch of momentum in the quarter, our efficiency programs continue to do well, the solid execution on the price increase, good demand across all customer segments and all geographies. And I think the capital investments that we've made over the last few years have been a major factor in helping us deliver this quarter and will help us in the quarters ahead. So we emerge stronger as we said we would.
